text:
Churches, towers and noble palaces… a small picturesque town perched high on a hillside surrounded by olives trees as far as one can see : come explore Trevi!

Trevi is known as the “capital of olive oil” forआणखी the production of extra virgin olive oil – an oil known and appreciated everywhere for its properties but it’s also a place of great charm and magic with its massive defensive walls, dating back to Roman times , and its medieval center characterize by a network of narrow streets.

Are you ready to discover one of the most fascinating hamlets of Umbria?
Join us: https://nextstop-italy.com/virtual-tours/trevi-capital-oil/

#virtualworld #italygram #ravelloitaly #umbria #renaissanceart #hilltown #umbriagram #assisi #virtualtour #medievalart #umbriatourism #Spello #hiddenparadise #vacationmood #italytravel #italyiloveyou #hilltopviews

,

text:
My 2 teenage children and myself will be visiting Venice, Florence, and Rome the second week of November. We have never been abroad, can anyone give me any tips or what to expect while there. What are some trips to making the most out our money? What are some absolute must see places since we have limited time in each place?
Thank you in advance for any information you can provide!

comments.comment_text: We too, will be in those cities for 12 days during this time. It’s my 1st trip to Italy, and I’m very excited. What days are you in Florence?

I would recommend an organized tour or the tour guide company mentioned above if this is your first trip to Italy. If your time is limited and you want to see the major sites, your guide should know how to navigate and the easiest methods of transport. Also if something should occur, they can help you handle it.
Once you understand how the trains and buses operate, how to buy tickets, what areas to avoid etc.; you may be ready for solo travel without guides.
My first trip to Europe was done at age 40. We rented a car and followed our noses from Zurich thru northern Italy and then back through the Dolomites, Austria and flew out of Munich. I did much of the driving which meant I didn’t see as much as we moved about. It was like being an adult child because you didn’t understand a lot.
I understand Italian so the Italian portion of the trip was easier but customs are different. There are often no words in another language for common English words. For example, there is no way to easily find overnight parking in Italy. They use the term custodial parking.
My point is that you have to make lots of guesses and assumptions when you travel in a foreign country on your own. It is much more relaxing and efficient to rely on people who know the ropes.

What is really great is asking your teenagers to look online for ideas in each city you're going to. #1 they are online all the time anyway, #2 it helps them learn about where they are going prior to arriving.#3 it gets them involved in the trip planning process and creates ideas and discussion and excitement. Don't do all the planning, let them get involved.

Fear is not real. It is a product of your thought you create. Do not misunderstand me. It is very real but fear is a choice. All I’m trying to say is with you need not to fear about losing your money, you can only lose it somewhere else but not with sir Luke Donald
We are here now with our teens. The best part about traveling with kids this age is they like to stay up late and cities are all very alive at night!

Wake up super early if you want to get good pictures of the iconic things such as the Trevi fountain, Spanish steps, etc. Book ahead on all the tours and make sure they say "skip the line". Make reservations for dinners, the great ones will be full and you can't walk up. Make sure to ask for the dinner bill, they will not bring it unless you ask. Understand that places close and there aren't a ton of places around lunch time. So either fill up in the am and know you won't find much until dinner.

Bring an umbrella and a warm coat, if you are spending a week total, do walking tours for 3 days in Rome, 2 Florence and 2 Venice. After the week you will decide where to go on your next trip but don’t forget the Amalfi coast. You will love all!

Buy Corinna Cooke - Author
books, all your questions will be answered. Have a great time.
Recommend Verona for a couple of days also.
U going in winter?

We had no trouble nor saw any pickpockets; the weather is about the same as mid US- take the train!!! Eat lots of different pastas, pizzas, daily gelato, tiramisu, and cannolis! Schedule a cooking class and Tuscany wine tour/lunch with wine tastings, take a gondola ride, shop the sidewalk shops: buy leather belts, bags, sandals. Buy hand painted pottery. Walk, walk, walk!b( Buy and take a European plug end adapter-we bought on Amazon with 2 phone chargers.

Do a small group cooking class. You go into a local’s home. Lots of fun to learn to make fresh pasta and tiramisu- then eat it of course! That’s a nice break from the usual running running running .

Use a travel agent to help with all the details- it takes the stress out of the equation and will give you confidence.
I wouldn’t recommend going to the Vatican. I went and it was the low point of many things we did there for two days.
Have a wonderful time! Everything will be perfect The Roman Forum, Vatican City. Is something special. Florence City and Venice you will love it all.

Hello. We’re taking a tour in Northern Italy in July 2024. We will be on our own in the Amalfi coast. Sorrento was recommended to me to stay in to visit the other areas around. Any Sorrento hotel or other recommendations
?
Also, we have a free day in Florence/
Tuscany. Any restaurant or other recommendations
? No children will be with us.

1. It’s a different country, so things will be different. 2. No matter what, you can’t do/
see it all, so don’t rush and just enjoy it. 3. Be vigilant like you would in any large US city. 4. If you get lost, don’t get frustrated…look at like this: this is a part of town you otherwise wouldn’t have seen, so take it all in. If you’re lost, you’re probably seeing more of the real Italy than if you stayed on the beaten path.

Just came back from a week in Venice, and it almost didn't seem like enough time. There is so much to see and do. When I return I will be staying in the Dorsodouro/San Polo area (particularly where they meet). Everywhere is walkable in Venice but these two neighborhoods, in particular, offer so much more IMO (restaurants, shops, museums, etc.) and we found ourselves spending more days there than around the crowded touristy over-priced San Marco area. It also just feels more local and it's cheaper. But on the other end of things don't forget this super charming bookstore - https://
www.atlasobscura
.com/places/
libreria-acqua-a
lta

I have visited all three, Travel light! If there are things you absolutely want to see pay the extra and book ahead. Rome, certainly the Vatican etc. But Florence WOW - we have just returned. Duomo Cathedral, Uffizi Gallery, and David in the Gallery- definately need to book in advance, we were there in May. We didnt book David and could not get in. Look at a combined ticket for the Duomo, Bell Tower, Uffizi Gallery in Florence, we thought it was really good value
Have lots of fun!

We just stayed at a cute air b n b in Venice that was a great location if your Interested - it just had a lot of stairs so if you have any kind of mobility problems not for you!
I really enjoyed murano and Burano- take the ferry yourself not a tour because they rush you!
Three cities is too much in one week. You will not really experience Italy that way. Choose one city and allow yourself time to really explore it.

Venice is deralict of local Venetians! Mass tourism has driven venetians to other islands and so for beauty it is unique but for local experiences and seeing people living there it us over! People have left and tourists have taken over with cameras and graffiti. The best of unique Venice was 20-50yrs ago. 😢

Romewise.com and Florencewise.co
m are so wonderful that you will want every city to have a site that is so good.
Do a culinary and culture tour on day one in each place if possible. You will learn so much about the cities, especially off-the-beaten path spots.

Pack layers - been to Rome in Nov and was roasted!
Book ‘hop on hop off’ for Rome to help get your bearings.
Book walking tours for all three - then decide where you’d like to see more of.
Don’t overthink it - just enjoy. All fabulous.

Wow! How blessed you are!
Venice: Doesn’t matter what you do there - it’s ALL amazing. If you have more than a couple of days there take a boat ride over to the island of Marano to see the glass making, then on to the island of Burano which is just exquisite.
Florence: must visit the Pont Avechio.

Rome - do the full Colosseum tour including underground where the gladiators and animals were kept. A night tour of it was perfect. The Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, Tour of the Vatican and Sistine Chapel, Tour the Catacombs there are many, go ride bikes through some of the old Appian Way, walk around in Trastevere and eat there. Walk around Campo de’ Fiori and Piazza Navona.
Venice- take a canal ride even on one of the regular boats, it doesn’t have to be a gondola. Go take a tour of Doge’s Palace the prison and the Bridge of Sighs. Go to Murano to watch the glassblower make something. Also go to Burano to see all of the beautiful colored houses on the canals.
Florence - book a trip to the Duomo in advance. It might be free but you still need a ticket in advance. Otherwise they won’t let you go to the top. It’s an unbelievable view of Florence. Well worth it. Take a golf cart tour to the top of piazelle Michaelangelo. I believe it is where he did a lot of his work. Go see the Statue of David and walk the Ponte Vecchio Bridge. The Piazza dell a Signoria was neat to walk around. Great leather if you need anything.
You’ll need the most time in Rome.

Just returned from 17 days in Italy. Loved it. We were in northern Italy for our son and and wife’s Italian wedding. She’s from Italy. Went to Florence and Venice, also. Advice - get your tickets well in advance for any sights that require them. Florence must sees are Uffizi museum and Academia museum. Venice - St Mark’s cathedral (that I wasn’t able to get tickets for since I didn’t plan ahead). Our apartment was right next to it so we saw the outside, but couldn’t go in. We took a private gondola ride with Luca who told us the history and info on all that we saw. If you look up gondola tours in Venice, you’ll find him. He’s great! We did an hour ride. Venice - get a multi day ticket for the vaporettos (water buses that continually run). You can get on and off at whatever stop you want. We loved getting on one in early evening and just enjoying being on the water and cooling down.
Take me lol, have a wonderful time,

Don't drive in Italy they are nuts, don't eat in the tourist places they suck and they have 10,000 new customers a day so they don't care about the quality of their food, talk to the taxi people and ask where they eat. And wear purses with azipper and flap over because the pick pockets gypsies are everywhere. Venice is beautiful and unique but a little boring and they aren't crazy about tourists, time is very fun and awesome but had the most pick pockets so good on to your stuff it's also very touristy so don't be afraid to walk off the beaten path, Florence is my absolute favorite, it is gorgeous I think we've more beautiful then Venice, the architecture is a mix of Roman, medieval, and Renaissance, and it's amazing. Again watch your wallet these are professional picks pockets they will steal your watch while your looking at it and you won't even notice, get a watch that fold clips not that slip clips. Other wise have fun and enjoy the beautiful people and country!
Florence “the David” is a must. How much time in each place?

Just a tip. They’ll probably be hustlers out there trying to sell you a product. Don’t let them put an item such as a bracelet on your arm saying I’m giving it to you. It’s not for free. That happened to my daughter and I when we were in Rome. They are very persistent. Be firm and say no then, keep moving. Try not to give eye contact as if you’re interested. Nothing to be afraid of that’s everywhere. …. enjoy. Cities are beautiful.

If you plan to visit any churches, be sure to wear clothes past the knee. Uber does not exist. Busses are a plenty but always know 2 bus lines to get back to your rental. We were stranded late in the evening on our way back to our hotel bc there was an accident in one of the roundabouts. The bus driver pulled over and put us all out. The bus ticket was reusable for up to 90 minutes (I believe) from start of original boarding.

Bring only carry on luggage so you can easily move around on public transport. Get money from atms upon arrival. Stay awake until 10 pm your first night despite the temptation to nap. Go off the beaten path rather than all the touristy places. Don’t obsess about safety. These places are likely safer than where you live
Purchase train tickets in advance with assigned seats!

My family went in June. My husband and children (age 15 and 11) had never been over seas. Had. Great time. Did a great walking tour in Rome. Highly suggest. And it was free! Email for a reservation and tip the guide accordingly. Rome's free ultimate walking tour. Check it out!
Take the hop on/ hop off bus entire route and then home hack to places that interest you.
Looking for a villa to rent in Tuscany fall of 2024; not in a remote area… for family of 6 adults, 2 children. Preferably in close proximity to a village. I keep coming up empty. Any ideas?

Pack light
1 suitcase medium size
In a lot of cities you have to handle your own suitcase
Venice especially tons of bridges there
up and down it was horrible
I brought an xlarge and med suitcase it was a struggle
Also backpacks are a great idea

Nov will be a great time…less people. Just be smart with the bag you take out with you. Venice: I recommend taking a water taxi from the airport to your hotel (look at Viator for a shared one), just getting lost in all the random streets, eat in places off the beaten path (cheaper and better food), and take a gondola ride that starts in the smaller canals avoiding the grand canal (so much more interesting and pricing is the same for all gondolas, no reservation needed in early Nov). Florence: get a glass of wine during happy hour from the wine window at Babae (closed Mondays), download a walking tour of the city, check out the art in front of the Uffizi museum (go into museum if you like looking at historic art), go to the Boboli gardens at sundown to see the city view, book a ticket to see David at the Acedemia Gallery, take a day tour into Tuscany for a pizza/gelato class or pasta class (Viator) and/or a day tour to Cinque Terre. Rome: Colosseum with underground access and Roman Forum, Vatican museums, have dinner in the Jewish quarter and Trastevere.

We were just in Rome in April. Flew non-Stop from LAX. I HIGHLY recommend ITA ( was Alitalia ) Fantastic experience.
We stayed at the Hotel Grand Palatino. Highly recommended. About 3 blocks from the Colosseum and Forum. Great staff, fantastic breakfast. Get a crossbody purse from PacSafe and always carry it in front of you. We carried pacSafe pouches and purses and had no problem. The Palatino is a great location. The street behind the hotel is alive with locals in the evening with pastry shops a pin and restaurants. We will stay there again.

I took my young adult daughter on a 17 day trip through Italy. We used the trains exclusively, stayed in VRBO flats, read Rick Steves' books cover to cover to help create our itinerary, used Viator and Get Your Guide for excellent guided tours and skip-the-line entrances to museums, etc. Have a wonderful time making memories together.

We stayed here in May 23 in Rome
And Summertime
In
Florence - plumeguide both were wonderful and walking distance to centres .l

Download free Rom2rio app. Enter 2 cities you wish to travel between, this will give you the distance, time, choice of buses, trains, ferries etc. A great tool for planning. Book fast trains in advance, price will be cheaper. Only book trains etc when you have booked airfares, then accommodation. Use youtube to check the places you want to go to.... also choose a smaller city/village to wander around & relax & feel like a local. Try Assisi in Umbria or Siena in Tuscany. Both south of Florence, can visit on way back to Rome. Fly into the north, out of the south or vise a versa.

Rome needs more time than Venice and Florence- there is so much to see without spending a lot of money- ie amazing churches and ruins all around. Have the kids do some research to engage them. We did ebike tour in Florence that kids liked. We also spent extra $ on private transportation from airports/
trains to hotels (well worth it )-
Start looking at viator or similar app for excursion ideas
Keep your eyes on your purse, phones etc- watch YouTube videos on Italy planning- very helpful too🇮🇹🇮🇹
Burger joint in Levito
Oh and if you do all the planning wrong you will still be in Italy and it will be amazing 🇮🇹🇮🇹🇮🇹
The convent in Rome a great, central, fair price place to stay. Florence as well.
Buy Rick Steve's Italy book

Pack light and do bits of laundry in your hotel or wherever you’re staying. We are here now (doing the same three cities) and I have just washed things out in the bathroom and hung them to dry. No need to pay for that service. It is much easier and cheaper. I purchased a Travelon bag to secure belongings and have felt quite safe with my valuables - you can unhook the strap when at restaurants and hook it around the chair so it won’t get grabbed although I have not seen that happen. I live in a large urban area so am hyper aware anyway. We have done tons of tours with The Tour Guy and CityWonders, etc… which have been great and have afforded us the ability to skip lines and see everything really quickly and efficiently.

Just got back from Florence. Buses and trams are the same ticket, valid for 90 minutes, so you can take 2 journeys plus a coffee stop for 2 euros a time. We used Google maps to find the best routes. Don’t just look at the first option as it may be quicker but involve more walking, not ideal if too hot or rainy.

We spent very little on sightseeing in Florence. Took a bus to the lookout (Piazzale Michelangelo) then another to the flea market at Santo Spirito (Sundays). From there it’s a short walk to the Ponte Vecchio and another to the Duomo.
Sam Cowie would you please pm me your Airbnb for Rome Florence? Many thanks!
The Vatican Trevi fountain Pompeii .

Forget big tour groups. In these cuties, book tours with “JustLocals”The
y are tours given by young adults (20-somethings)
who love their city. The tour is just your family. It’s so fun for teens to see and hear it from a cool older “kid”. I took my 19 year old girls and we all loved the guides we had and saw and learned things wd never would have. This is about piquing your teens interest in culture and more travel. They’ll totally love it. Check the website.

Hi All, to everyone that asked for my recommendation for accommodation I will just post here. There were so many requests so hope that is ok.

Venice - we stayed on the island. The Airbnb was beautiful and on the canal. We had to catch a waterbus across to the mainland, which was no problem but it was €9.50 each way. The villa had one double bedroom and 2 singles were in the living room, along with chairs and a table - it worked ok. It was a short walk to a co-op and restaurants. If you want a quiet stay, this is the place. Very clean and host was very helpful. Waterbus also takes you back to the train Termini. Eating was reasonably priced.

Calle delle erbe
Giudecca, Venice, 30133, Italy

Florence - we stayed at Plus Florence which is a hostel but we had a private room with 4 single beds and a huge private ensuite. It was about a 10 min walk to the main Termini. The buffet breakfast is cheap. Very close to the markets. A bit of a walk to the pointe vecchio but we stopped along the way for a drink etc. The pool gets busy and very popular with the 20ish year olds but they were no bother. We are a family of 4 and there were other families there.

Plus Florence
Via Santa Caterina D'Alessandria 15, Florence, 50129, Italy

Rome - we stayed in the Vatican area which was not our initial choice but our original accommodation was cancelled on us so we were left with whatever was available on our budget. This apartment is immaculate! 3 double rooms all with ensuites. Great air con. Short walk to the metro which made it very easy to get around. Many restaurants around the area but didn’t offer a great deal if you’re looking to shop. There were markets nearby which offered some cheap clothing. The apartment exceeded our expectations. Host was very easy to deal with.

Vatican Townhouse
Viale Giulio Cesare, Vaticano Prati , Rome, 00192, Italy

Hope that helps. Let me know if you have any other questions ☺️

Make sure you hire a tour guide if you are going to see the Vatican. We are not big on tours but we were so glad we did that. I don't know if my friend Yuval Lahav is still doing tours but I'm sure you wouldn't be disappointed. He's on FB. Also, make sure you eat gelato EVERYWHERE you go!

Download Rick Steve’s app! We used The Tour Guy for our guided tours In Rome (Vatican and Colosseum)-perf
ect! *** Vatican headsets broke up if you were not close to your guide because obviously the reception in there isn’t the best. Take good water bottles! Italy-Rome especially has free, cold & delicious water everywhere. We scheduled a one on one (small group) tour with Isuf (Airbnb)-he has 10 wonders of Rome tour that’s absolutely amazing! We had 3 days and was able to see so much! We are going to Venice tomorrow 😉 with our 2 teens. Glad it will be November. The heat has been the worse for us. ***good walking shoes and battery packs to charge your phones

Rick Steve’s books and web site give the best practical tips. In my opinion, Frommers and Fodors are good but Rick stands out for giving opinions and good advice on money maters and travel options in country. Read him and you should have a great time. Lots of folks travel using guide books and local or day tours. Trip Advisor app is a good source for local tours.
Learn a little bit of italian even the bare minimum goes a long way
In Florence do the moped and wine trip! Totally fun way to see countryside
It sounds, from you itinerary, that you are going with a tour. Heed their advice, as well as whatever you read here.
You should definitely start researching. Trains are a challenge if you are new to them in Europe. And definitely attempt the language. They dislike ppl assuming English.

It will be different than your hometown and embrace that. Learn at least a few years phrases to show respect. Meals in restaurants are slower on purpose - dining is to be enjoyed, not rushed through. Eat gelato every day - to help get the best…if the pistachio is bright green then they aren’t using fresh ingredients that make it tastier and you don’t want the really fluffy ones. My favorite from any city was in Florence at Vivoli.
I thought Venice was amazing. 2 days we were in San Marco area and it was great and then delta cancelled our flight home and rebooked us 3 days later and we moved to hotel in dorsoduro area because original hotel full and loved this new area maybe even more - bit less busy, but had great restaurants and shops and churches/
museums to visit without lines….and you can walk over bridge to San Marco. Used water taxi and really enjoyed traveling that way and doing that didn’t feel need do gondola we were going do. Sit toward back of water taxi and open top and ride standing up looking out. Also did water bus which is much cheaper.

Order some travel money belts that go under your pants in front. I never had to worry about anyone stealing my money. Then probably a cross purse goes over the front of you for cellphone and stuff. What they like to do is bump you or cause a commotion which distracts you. I had no problem but was given this advice. But watch the front of the purse. I bought my niece a leather one which would be hard to cut. She told me she was getting a nap sack. I just laughed at her. I said they can use a knife form behind and you’ll never know what happened.
Good choice for a first visit to Italy. These cities are very well documented so do a search and see what you would like. Eat in Trattorie where Italians eat, cheap and delicious.

A day trip to Pompeii is a must. Touristy? Of course. Amazing? Yes. And great for teens. My son was 10yo and even he thought it was super cool. They'll probably love an outdoor market shop + day-long cooking class, we did one with Luca outside of Florence last summer - fun for the whole family and so memorable.

-Florence: Academia (David), Mercato Centrale, Duomo and bell tower, walking food tour of Florence
-Rome: golf cart tour, pantheon, Trevi fountain, colosseum and Roman forum, st Peter’s and the Vatican museum, cooking class, catacombs, lots of Catholic Churches and artifacts 😉

Florence owns my heart. Be sure to purchase (in advance) “skip the line” tickets for places like the Academia (Statue of David) and the Uffizi Museum. Viator is a respectable/
trustworthy site for this. You can also purchase a variety of tours through them for all your destinations.

As you can see by all the comments, there is lots to see, do and be mindful of. All this information can be extremely overwhelming for someone who has never been overseas.

I would advise taking the tips and suggestions with you to a travel professional who can work with you to get the holiday you want, safely booking reputable accommodation, tours, transport etc.
If there is a fee then consider it worth it for the time, effort and knowledge they provide and the back up assistance should something change or not go to plan. There will still be plenty that you can plan for yourself, should you choose.

After having done it once, you may feel confident to "go it alone" in the future.

Our biggest expense was Uber around Rome we had a large group so didn’t wNt to try the busses
If you can ride train or bus you will save a ton of money
If you are eating in Venice, try the restaurants behind the square….the tables in the square are expensive, even for coffee….don’t be fooled when the waiter says please sit you will pay for it

Pack light! Carry on and personal is all you'll need. If your hotels do laundry or you are air bnb it use the washer and dryer. Trust me, you will enjoy the trip that much more with out having to lug checked bags on and off trains or the water busses.

Burano is a beautiful island if you have a decent time to spend in Venice. If you'll only be there for two or 3 days maybe just enjoy Venice. If you have longer definitely get to burano.

The further north in italy you go the more English speaking friendly it becomes. Definitely learn key phrases for rome. It will be very helpful. Don't rely on Google translate cuz it is not always accurate.

Bring comfortable shoes and drink all the limoncello!
Beware of thief’s working in hotels I had money stolen from my room safe key style in Florence
Good for you Sam Cowie! Love info as well.
Go fewer places, see more, and plan to go back. Trying to do everything in one trip dilutes the experience for me.

🙌 Congratulations
! The trip will be unforgettable. I promise. Now…
1. Make sure your Iphone battery is in working order. Also, bring portable battery & cord. Days will be long and you’ll want to photograph everything remarkable (to you).
There will be plenty.
2. Make sure you check handmade toys-items-stor
es. The craftmanship is spectacular, and some will merit both fotos & videos.
Trust me on this one.
3. Try to formally open each photography day with a specific location. That way, you’ll remember where you were and the day’s activities.
4. Check for specifics-Pieta
, David, Dante Alighieri’s home, Lord Byron’s apt in Venice. Certain references will make context palpable.
5. Gelato. Lemon is best, but please, don’t leave without proper photos!
6. Eat. Drink. Have coffee. Enjoy everything, and please, share your photos! 💐

Thank you

Take lots of Ana is from home, and their favourite spread so you can take easy sandwiches with you each day. These holidays are expensive and you only want to spend money on the GOOD snacks and meals. Stock up on new favourite snacks when you find grocery stores in your first destination.
Do the free walking tours in each city
It’s a cold month 🥲

Keep your valuables safe. Pickpockets are amazingly enterprising around favored sites. Try to buy tickets to important excursions ahead of time (e.g. Vatican City Basilica and Sistine Chapel, Uffizi Gallery, Doge’s Palace, etc.). You’re going in the off season, so crowds should be thinner, but lines were excruciatingly long this summer.
Venice is walkable, as is Florence. Transportation is plentiful in Rome.
Enjoy!!!
Trevi fountain is a must see
Pre-schedule a mass and visitation if you want to see the pope.

Venice is really walkable. An under $20 Chorus Pass pp gets you into 10-12 Churches and. The map that comes with it takes from one end to another. Stay somewhere really central and do all things right one day and left the second. End at San Marco every evening. Just walk and get lost. Give yourselves time to explore. We stayed at the Hotel Bel Sito. Reasonable, great breakfast, and central. Wonderful location, service and staff. My husband and I spent a week there in 2022. Used the pass and a tour of St Marks and throughly loved it all. You can do it without breaking the bank. If we saw a great spot we were interested for dinner we wrote it down so we could find our way back. That time of year get out and see things, enjoy the afternoon siesta and then go out for dinner, live like the Italian’s 🇮🇹❤️. I had the advantage of 2 years of no travel to plan. But watch and listen to all the Rick Steve’s videos and talks. They do help, You can do this!
Take some cheap was cloths. They don’t use them there. Enjoy every moment.
Be careful in Rome, I arrived today had 2 licks on my bag and still got pickpocketed
Get Rick Steves book on Italy.
Try to eat at restaurants slightly away from main attractions, where locals eat, prices are better too.

Bring good shoes for walking.
Nothing sucks worse the. Sore feet and you still to walk a bunch to get back to your place.
Everyone has different things they want to see. Look at the area and for what interest you in the area.

Enjoy ☺️ and one thing I always tell family and friends. Enjoy your day without stressing to go to every location that’s touristic. It can get overwhelming. Enjoy the food, gelato ( even if it’s cold) and their coffee shops ( their cafes and deserts are delicious).
Barbara De Luca

We went to Rome, Venice and Florence last May. My youngest was 11. I’d recommend booking a tour of the Coliseum, and they have a tour that’s more geared for kids at the Vatican. It was great for all of us! Our favorite activity was a Vespa tour with wine tasting and a meal just outside of Florence. It was the PERFECT day!

If you have status with hotel, should be able to get upgrade 4 in a room, have them read about cities before, give foundation when seeing in person….plan out days to take advantage for what you want to see with the kids….have two teens too, your kids will love it…have fun

Learn some simple phrases, questions in Italian. Familiarize yourself with central city maps so you can navigate streets. Skip restaurants that cater to tourists. Layer clothing and wear comfortable shoes.
Do a cooking class! We are a family of 4 with our kids being 21 and 17 and we had so much fun! They really enjoyed it! Cooking classes in Rome Pizza & Pasta School

Not sure how long you’ll be in Venice but I went there last year for a couple of day with my family. Went with a couple of teenagers and one of the best memories was us doing a Scavenger Hunt. Search on line. We made teams and had a competition. Definitely a fun couple of hours. We still talk/laugh about it! And I believe it was a total of maybe €20 to download.
You probably will need a coat.

Here are the top three answers to questions we see here.

1. Yes you can plan it without a travel agent. Just figure out the order with the way you want to do things. Check your local airports and the destinations to like up flights (google flights is the best).
Any activities spend the extra on skip the line.

2. Call your carrier and ask about their international plans. Pretty much all smartphones work anywhere. You just want to understand the billing.

3. Double check your credit cards to make sure they have no foreign transaction fees. If you plan and prepay everything before you leave, you can take one credit card and use that for everything while you’re there. You won’t be worrying about grabbing cash. Or the daily exchange rate. Visa and Mc are ok everywhere, Amex in populated areas, Discover never.

what I do is figure out my spending money. (I don’t do air bnb and we eat out every meal, so I budget $250 -300 a day. And I m out the money in my account, I swipe my credit card like crazy, then I pay the bill when I get home.
Get travel insurance, I suggest Allianz.
Water proof shoes or boots. We were there during high tide and the sidewalks were flooded.
Make sure to have Euro coins @ all times!!!! Many public restrooms charge and learned the hard way The ones that were actually manned they would not budge and accept credit card or American money!

Do some research about what museums etc you want to see
And purchase what you can online to save time
November should be fine though
Could be rainy and chilly
Be sure to have clothing for the rain
I lived in northern Italy and it was foggy and rainy quite a bit
In Nobvember
Depends on exchange rate, I got some Italian money here. At the time I was over there they did not want American money. Watch out for pickpockets and snatch and grab
Higly suggest Rolling Rome golf cart tours in Rome. Book now! There is also a golf cart company in Florence but not sure of the name. Enjoy!
Get the Rick Steve’s Italy book
Check out Rick Steves book!!!
What do you like to see ? Churches, history , vineyards.

Traveling with teenagers can be so fun! If your kids are willing, have them look for apps that will help them understand what they are seeing (Rick Steves has an app, for example, or they can check out Atlas Obscura which has rare and sometimes spooky sites listed that other tour books miss). Or they can hit up social media for sites to see and help make a wish list. They can look up restaurants as well.
Do not stand in lines to see building. Buy books of the places you want to see that way you see more
Have fun I just got back from Rome in florence. It was just beautiful

Be careful traveling by train ,etc. there are scammers that try to lure you pretending to be employees. Do not fall for it. Do not be gullible. Check credentials. Pick pockets also . … Make sure you have your passport, ID money credit cards well protected. Advise your teenagers also. There are also beggars pretending to be crippled, elderly or homeless or have realistic looking baby dolls asking for money. Just like any major city … be aware.. they target foreign visitors .

text: What do American citizens need to do to be able to drive in Italy? Thinking about renting a car in Siena and enjoy the beautiful countryside. Travelling in November. Thank you!

comments.comment_text: You need a valid driver’s license from your country. The international permit is only a translation of your license. The international permit is needed if, say, a police officer stops you and cannot read the language your license was issued in. The international drivers permit does not replace your license.

https://
www.discovercars
.com/
?a_aid=NextStop-
Italy.
If you have AAA they can help you

City driving is chaotic with little or no parking...don't
. Rural driving is easy. Get an international drivers license, watch routes for tolls, and beware of hidden camera speed traps.

Italian driver's may seem chaotic, but I can tell you they're very very alert ....(something missing in many North American drivers from my personal experience!... we've driven from the Swiss border down to the most southern tip of Sicily and quite honestly I can say, we never saw an accident...I'm sure they happen but we never saw one

Oh and beware of road scams where someone will say you damaged their car and want money from you, that did happen to us, but the evidence proved otherwise what they said happened couldn't have left our car untouched

In 2022, we got IDLs from AAA as non-members for $20 per license. It was fast and easy.

I’d still REALLY study a country’s traffic laws, though, especially signage, symbols and vocab. I thought I did, but when we got there I wished I’d done even more.
Hire a driver or train
your driver s license, that is it

International drivers license at AAA for $20. We were asked for it the last time we rented overseas. Bring your US drivers license too. It’s always better to have too much documentation For $20 it’s worth it.
Just get an international license. $20 at any AAA office
You probably won’t NEED an IDL to rent a car, or if you get stopped by police (which I did, twice - they laughed at the IDL) but you should get one in case of accident.

You just need to show them your US license. We’ve rented a car twice with Hertz. Get the extra insurance, it is definitely a must! The roads are like driving at the bumper car park. No rules, just suggestions. Have a great trip!
It’s called Siena and they just need to apply for an international driving permit

Have great courage

text: We’ll be in Sicily and Pompeii so can go up Etna and/or Vesuvius. Any recommendations on which one is best or should we do both?? TIA 😊😊

comments.comment_text:
These two volcanoes are completely different. We climbed both. In fact, we visited Pompeii one year and took an overnight ferry to Palermo the next day, picked up a rental car, ended up going to Monte Etna 2 weeks later. Etna is HUGE. Driving extremely winding road up to Piazzale Rifugio Sapienza was very scenic with all the previous lava flows and destroyed buildings.
In contrast, Monte Vesuvio is a very iconic one. Always visible from anywhere in Napoli. Easily accessible from both Herculaneum(Erc
olano) Pompeii. In fact, we did Vesuvio and Herculaneum in one day.
I cannot say which one is better than the other. Both active volcanoes are equally beautiful and dangerous. We appreciate both because we’ve done both. If you want to see much more of geothermal activity in greater Campania region, Campi Flegrei’s Solfatara in Pozzuoli is a great example.
both!

text: Hi. I’m just wondering if anyone has hired a car to travel around Italy instead of using public transport? How did you find it? Cost wise and cost wise compared to public transport. Did you find it gave you more time?

comments.comment_text: We did! No regrets. We saw things that people in public transport can't see. For example we went at Verrazzano winnery in toscane there is no bus to get there and if so you can not stop the bus to take pictures.We hired from Naples then give it back in Venise. For us it was the best option (we have a teenager with us).

We do it every year. We do a buy back car in Paris then travel as we like. It gets you away from the crowds. Several times this year we have been told we were the only Americans who ever stayed there. You get your own custom tour.
We go to Italy every year and rent a car. We love the flexibility. We don’t drive in Rome or Florence.
We always hire a car. I don’t know about time, but it does give you more flexibility. We have rarely had any difficulties

A car is necessary to adequately see Tuscany, Le Marche, and Puglia. It is useful in Sicily, too, to see many villages. (Just avoid larger towns and cities!) For the Amalfi Coast, Sorrento, Naples, Rome, Florence, Milan, and Venice, you not only don't need a car, but having one will also be a giant hassle. Messenger me if you want more of my notes on driving in Tuscany and on the Amalfi Coast.

We did this last week it was a last minute decision two days before arriving in Rome as we heard of the strikes and our Hotel was outside the city. We paid €150 for 6 days with Goldcar. We got to see so much more of Rome, we drove to Ostia beach twice, the military base, went to see the historical site Ostia Antica, we brought our sons to the water park Hydromania, we drove around Rome late at night just to see it all lit up, the air con in the car was such a relief after hours of walking in the sun. Get a small car easier to park and there's free parking on Sundays.
Take the bus, they are easy but watch your wallets.

We've been to Italy four times and have had a car for all or part of the trip in each one. Worked fine. We like to get out in the "boonies" where there's no other tourists and get a flavor of the "real" Italy and the car allows us to do that.
Car hire give you freedom to travel anywhere anytime, prices are reasonable but you need to test the market for best price.

I prefer to hire a car or have my own car. I've more freedom and with Google maps I can get anywhere. Definitely more expensive that public transport ( rental, insurance, highway toll, gas) but I prefer it ( no time limits, can change plans last minute, air condition).
You get it at the airport and drop it at the airport. I did the same in other countries too.
If you can get a hybrid ( doesn't need to be charged)car you'll spend less on gas
Can anyone recommend a private driver from Rome airport to the Salerno area?
Is there a preferred rental company in Italy ?

We rent outside of the cities. It’s easy and yes, so much more flexibility and get to see places that are out of the way.
Tuscany to me a car is a must have! So many smaller towns don’t have train stations etc and the Val de Orcia is just beautiful to drive through!

We take the train to a smaller city and rent there. From Rome we rented in Orvieto and it was great, easy etc!

I have driven all over Italy and Iove it. So much free time and getting lost you find some of the best places. We drove to Pisa and then Lucca and on the way was this fabulous pasticceria with so many beautiful cakes, pastries and Gelato. We visited the amazing hilltop village of Todi. Places we would have never found without a car.

We’ve driven the length and breadth of Italy more times than I can count. honestly it’s our preferred way to travel. The trains are fine for going from big city to big city but if you’re interested in going from small town to small town the car is far superior. It’s also great for spontaneity and flexibility. If you see something interesting along the way you can stop to visit it.

Cost wise. That depends on a lot of things. First the total cost of train travel is multiplied by the number of people in your group because each person will have to buy a ticket. But with car travel the total cost will be divided by the number of people so the per person transportation cost can be less. With 2, 3 or 4 people we’ve often found the car to be less expensive. For one person the train is usually cheaper. You pretty much have to price each trip out both ways to determine which is in your financial
Interest. Last, renting from the airport tends to be more expensive than renting from a downtown location. And because certain train routes cost more than others your specific itinerary and destinations make generalizations
difficult. You have a lot of things to price out!!

The trick is to accurately calculate the actual total cost. With a car you have to include the cost of the rental itself, insurance, gas, tolls, and parking fees. With the train you have to include the cost of a taxi between your lodging & the train station every time you arrive and leave a location. Those are the total costs to compare before making a decision.

When renting be aware that most European rental cars are manuals. If you require an automatic the price will increase and you’ll have to reserve well in advance because the supply is limited. Also be aware that returning the car to a different location than where you picked it up will increase your cost, sometimes significantly.

Lots of people will try to discourage you from driving. Yes it can be a challenge at times and the Italians generally drive aggressively. If you yourself are afraid to drive there that would be a good reason not to. But I wouldn’t let the fears of others convince me not to drive. Most of us have enough fears to worry about without borrowing those of others. I’d suggest you talk to people who have actually driven in Italy rather than people who haven’t.

Research the Limited transportation zones and know the road sign for that. Those are zones in cities that only locals can drive
In. (This is to lessen traffic congestion, to allow pedestrians to safely use the streets and sidewalks and to prevent car exhaust from harming ancient buildings.) license plate numbers belonging to each zone are registered. Cameras are set up at intersections to take photos of cars entering the zones. Those entering with license plates not registered will be fined. The camera takes great photos of both the plate and the driver so it’s hard to dispute the fine. The zones are always marked and always marked in such a way that you can make a turn to avoid entering the xone. The problem is many tourists don’t see the signs or are too nervous about driving to turn. Some poor souls drive in and out of limited zones multiple times and are fined for each and every infraction. It takes a while for the driver to be traced through the license plate and the car rental agency so the driver might not receive notice of the fine until months after the trip. And the amount can be significant depending on how many times a zone was entered. So it’s important to Google that sign so you’ll recognize it.

Otherwise big city driving is pretty much like big city driving everywhere else. Country roads are country roads everywhere and highways are highways . But small villages laid out before the invention of cars were designed for walkers. They might take a bit of getting used to.

But truthfully self driving can be a very rewarding way to explore Italy.

On my way to scicly where it’s over 100s. Everywhere is the same. Drink lots of water stay hydrated and enjoy. Definitely have a battery operated fan. Sweat rags you can wet for your neck.
If you like lakes Garda lake is a good option. It has beautiful frontlakes where you can swimm in clean water: Malcesine
Good idea. We were there during a 100 degree heat wave a few years ago and it was miserable. I would agree with you to make alternative plans.
Australia, its cold here. Seriously a pool, or beach with shade, a/c. Not sure where to recommend as its probably packed everywhere.

We are from inland Australia and very accustomed to dry heat. The humidity can be tough, but be sun smart - sunscreen, hat, sunglasses, loose light coverings (long sleeved light linen has been a saviour). Seek shade wherever you can (even if that’s just walking on the other side of the road) and drink plenty of water (at home we were taught 200ml for every 20 minutes in the sun).
We’ve spent 2 weeks here - Milan, Venice, Rome, Sorrento and now Naples.
Just pick your timing! Early mornings and evenings are best with an air conditioned museum and/or hotel siesta in the heat of the day.
The colosseum tour was probably the biggest struggle, but worth it. The guide was helpful in finding shady areas with breezy thoroughfares.
My partner loves to walk around new cities but we opted for an air conditioned Uber where we could (not an option in some places - but the scooters are a good option in Florence) and I found it helped “preserve” stamina!
Work smarter not harder, don’t miss out on the beautiful places on offer 😊

Once, just once we were in Italy at the end of May- never again! It was 106 for quite a few days in a row. That taught us never to travel in early summer, summer or late summer again! We now travel off season in mid to late fall and early spring. I know some of you have children and can’t travel at certain times because of school schedules. But, I advise to leave the kids home with grandma and grandpa and go off season. You will enjoy it so much more and there are no crowds and your children won’t be miserable!
Lake Como should be a lot cooler than Rome.
Heat tolerance varies widely. As you described it will ruin your trip maybe visit in cooler months if you have flexibility
Michelle Sloan Kendal Achurch-Ihle - I’d say going in term 3 holidays (and maybe an extra week?) is going to be nicer than July holidays! I love the heat but sightseeing in 40 degrees - no thank you!

I would recommand a beach in Northern Italy from Venice until Trieste.There are a lot of beaches from Venice to the North,Jesolo,Bi
bbione,Lignagno
,Grado,Sistiana
and Trieste itself,a very beautiful City and 20 km from the border to Slovenja and Croatia with also small beautiful villages and beaches.
Go to Dolomites!!!! Even at the seaside it's quite hot now,like 40°C.
We’re in Rome right now. Dear God I’ve never sweated this much! 😂
Spent last week in Florence and Rome. Avoid it! Waaaaayyyy too hot. It ruined it for us in so many levels

We were in Rome for 3 days and in Florence for the last 4. Rome was incredibly hot - we had day excursions and it was brutal. We've been in Florence for the last 3 days and it is also unseasonably hot; even the locals were saying so. The evenings have been much better though, especially with the breeze. Hydrate at every opportunity, walk in the shade if possible, and eat plenty of gelato!

We’ve been in Rome for 2 weeks now.

I’m from freezing cold Finland and I’m enjoying the weather in Rome 😄

Tomorrow heading to Amalfi coast.
We are going in late September. Hoping it’s a bit cooler but fully expect it to still be warm.
The heat was tough in Rome - we did mornings and nights and napped during the day in the AC. We head to Florence tomorrow. I’m hoping it’s a little better but I’m guessing it won’t be.
I’m going to Sardinia I can’t wait heatwave or not I’m Ireland we have rain sun wind July was a wash out

it was definitely hot but bearable if you’re used to the heat. it may sound a bit unconventional but we woke up super early (before sunrise) to get out and see the sights then came back just before midday to nap/wait it out and then head out later at 5/6pm as it starts to cool down 🙂
I think that would be a very smart move. Being near water always helps with the heat. Of course millions will have the same idea. Good luck!

We left Florence after3 days of extreme heat and headed for the beach at Rimini - great beach but really crowded this weekend - a comic-con event on so thousands of young ones all dressed up, they must have been so hot in their costumes!! But at least we could go swimming and cool off.
Try Dolomite Mountains

Yeah, I'm here with my family now. We came bc some are students and my sister in law is a teacher. This will be the last time I come in July. We made the best of it. We had a great time, but it is extremely hot. I love Rome, but I felt like there was no escaping the heat. Florence was extremely hot too, but it was less walking outside.
why not to the mountains? Trentino Alto Adige Dolomites: lake braies, 3 cime di lavaredo, Cortina d’Ampezzo, Auronzo, lake Misurina
Dolomites- lago do Garda area or other lake areas Dro, Ledro, Braise?

Plan your outdoor activities etc... earlier in the day...keep a
moist or wet towel with you...carry extra water or buy pedialyte to hydrate...Find shade...Wishing
u a wonderful vacay!😎
Mountain regions sometimes cooler especially at night. Dolomiti are amazing
Head to the hills !!!
I am in Florence now and it is brutal. It is my first time but I do not think we will see everything!
I’m here in Rome now and we only go out in early am or after 7pm. Stay inside during midday to beat the heat.
Florence’s heat was the worst for me🥵 We just did everything before 12pm that meant to be up at 6 and going! Then went back to AC in our room and out again at 5:30pm walking in the shaded areas🤗
Upper 30s and low 40s in Rome. I'd go swim in the beautiful sea and come back in the fall/spring.. But also, you can take the subway in Rome to Ostia and swim in the sea as well.
Just returned from Florence and Rome…🔥🔥🔥🥵
The heat is crazy! I'm in Rome at the moment and it is insanely hot. It does put a damper on things like going out
Too hot definitely ruins it

I second that. We are in Rome too and it’s definitely put a damper on some of our plans. We leave Tuesday and I was hoping to see a few more things but Rome is crazy hot. We have been in Italy two weeks and these last two days have been really sweltering. We haven’t even seen the colosseum or Roman forum because it’s about 30 minutes from where we are and all outside so neither my husband or I want to be out in that. Early morning and evenings have been better, but it’s pretty hot. Try and do indoor air conditioned things in the middle of the day. We took a break most afternoons for a while and went back out in the evenings. It’s still been fun but we did opt out of some things because of the heat.
It's raining in mid/northern UK at the moment....🙄

Yes we’ve come from Maiori and wishers made that our last stop. We are in Orvieto and it’s ok I think 33c today but not really crowded we are heading to Firenze and Roma but will try and keep out of the heat in the middle of the day. Carrying a cheap spray bottle with water 💦 and a hat . I can’t believe how many do not even have a hat I also have an umbrella, sunscreen and water . We are Aussies but still find it challenging in the middle of the day
Sanremo on Liguria coast, have beach, gardens, vegetation, and temperatures is low then Florence and Rome, and are many to visit in that area, Imperia, Bussana, Ventimiglia, Dolceaqua .

A friend in Rome told me this week that they’re having record high temps. I would be miserable.

We are in Rome now from Florida. The heat is warm but the humidity is way less than home. I don’t think it’s too bad. Keep a water bottle handy and fill at all the public water fountains/
springs.

Just been to Florence and now in rome . I’d skip both …too hot and crowded . I wish I’d stayed near the coast . I’m from Sydney and used to the heat but this is next level and with the crowds and no seaside , I would go elsewhere !
We have been here 10 days, and it is EXTREMELY hot! We lived in Las Vegas for 40+ years, and it is hotter here. It is very crowded, and shade is hard to find.

Riccione was pretty nice if like sandy beaches

And I forget the town we stopped at but it had rocky beaches on the west coast that had a delicious place to eat called the jungle I think it was 😍😍

If need something close to Florence
Go to the Elsa trail waterfall!!!!! (Enter at the southern point if don't want to hike) absolutely gorgeous and cooling! 😍😍😍😍

Not sure where you are now but I recommend the coastline between Viareggio & Marina di Massa. Beautiful flat coastline with lots of pretty towns/villages on the coast or close by inland. We’ve been going to Marina di Pietrasanta for the past 25 years - we live in England - absolutely love it. Tons of fab hotels 3-5*. Forte dei Marmi is expensive town so we gofor the Weds & Sun markets & always have our coffee standing at the bar - €1.20 instead of €5.we hire bikes as there’s a fab cycle path 8K alongside the coast. Btw we’re 68 & 70 - still cycling in Italy!
The coast is beautiful everywhere. If you have the chance, Tuscany has nice towns on the beach and wonderful islands very close by boat (you can board the car too), like Giglio or Elba Island!
We are in Florence and it’s very hot. Manageable with a cocktail and lots of water. Venice was beautiful! We cancelled our day trip to Rome. 110 degrees is not fun!
Currently in Florence and tbh it's not very enjoyable with this heat. (And crowds)

We are in Rome, start our day early and retreat back to our hotel to shower, cool and nap after lunch. Then go back out at 5! However it is our second time here so not really rushing to see all the attractions
Avoid big cities that are overheating, go in the rural country or the sea, avoid midday to visit, enjoy nights out!
Head to Ireland.

Overcrowded, hot and humid (you should visit in the spring or fall); go to the Tuscan archipelago if you can or Versilia (I’m having drinks now in Seravezza and it’s super cool, might even get chilly).
I’ve been in Naples the last 3 days and just got to amalfi. It is HOT.

Keep your expectations in check, to have a successful visit. What I mean by that is — be okay with going back to your apartment/
hotel for 5-6 hours midday. We went out in the early AM and late PM, only. Hydrate more than you think is necessary to help cope.

We were in Rome because I had booked the Musei Vaticani tour and Villa Borghese museum tickets in advance, afterwards we went to Tivoli and now we are in Frascati and we're enjoying every minute since we are doing what the locals do, eating typical food etc. Can't stand the heat and overcrowded Rome. We have considered in coming in cooler months.
We tend to do inter city in April or Oct x
Isola d’Elba
Go to the mountains! Valle d'Aosta is beautiful, I suggest you Courmayeur or try dolomiti!

text: Will be visiting Italy in November and wondering what is required to drive a vehicle while there?

comments.comment_text: An international driver’s license…Get one at AAA. The city driving is chaotic with little parking. Rural driving is easy and fun, just beware of no vehicle zones and camera speed traps. We always get the complete rental insurance package.
Bigger question is why you want to drive? Train is easy and driving in Italy is not fun
International license and proof of third party insurance

From 15 November (in our part of Italy but it varies on specific timing in different regions) all cars are required to either have snow types or all weather tyres fitted OR to carry snow chains. Hire companies seldom supply snow chains so make sure you insist on them supplying them and check the exact date it comes into force in the region/s you will be travelling in
My time in Europe found it easier to walk or use public transportation (they have a lot) then trying to drive...if u have a fair distance to go and are time restricted use a taxi...
